text: In fact, if they are trying to figure out how the video got posted in the first place, to see if there are other accessories to the crime, it seems like a modest request. Hard to see why a "please don't delete things" is such an unreasonable request to merit such a response.
author: GerryDales

text: His emails simply asked, "please do not delete any records" and "what would be the legal way to go about requesting them." There is nothing in the request that says "turn this over" nor "so we can go after people for just posting the video." 1/2
author: GerryDales

text: When I ready the email in this tweet, and then read what the email it was in response to, I don't think "protecting privacy wooooo!!!", but rather, "what a jerk." The first email was polite, non-threatening, and asking what they needed to do legally. And, IMO, reasonable.

text: You don't see the original tweet if you quote tweet a tweet that had been quote tweeted. No recursion, sadly.

text: I thought of likely reason #3. Concessions. Especially with the growth of reserved seating, people don't get to the theaters as far before the scheduled showtime now. Extended trailers, especially as people get used to there being so many, gives folks the time to buy.
